description: The First Floor focuses on later Renaissance, Baroque, and major European schools, including the renowned Caravaggio collection.

items.title: Contini-Bonacossi Collection
items.description: A curated selection of paintings, sculptures, and decorative arts displayed across several rooms. It adds depth to the Uffizi visit by showing important works alongside furniture and objects that help visitors understand collecting and taste in different periods.

items.title: Saint Lawrence Martyred
items.description: A dramatic Baroque sculpture centered on the martyrdom of Saint Lawrence. Bernini is known for pushing stone toward lifelike intensity - here the emotion and physical tension are meant to be felt up close.

image.alt: Gian Lorenzo Bernini, Saint Lawrence Martyred

viewing_tips: Notice how Bernini captures the moment of agony
The work was created when Bernini was only about 18 years old
Compare with his later, more refined works

items.title: Collection of Artists' Self-Portraits
items.description: One of the world's most important collections of artists' self-portraits, organized across multiple rooms by period and theme. It offers a rare chance to see how artists presented themselves - socially, psychologically, and professionally - over the centuries.

items.title: The 16th Century
items.description: A starting point for the Cinquecento (1500s) route on the First Floor, introducing the shift toward mature Renaissance styles and the variety of regional schools represented in the Uffizi.

items.title: Madonna with the Long Neck
items.description: A hallmark of Mannerism: elegant distortions, elongated proportions, and a deliberately unusual spatial design. The effect is both refined and unsettling, replacing Renaissance balance with a more expressive, stylized beauty.

image.alt: Parmigianino, Madonna with the Long Neck

viewing_tips: Notice the impossibly elongated neck and fingers
The tiny prophet in the lower right seems in a different scale
The work was left unfinished at Parmigianino's death

items.title: Rest on the Flight into Egypt
items.description: A tender Holy Family moment from the Flight into Egypt. Correggio is admired for soft transitions of light and shade and a warmth that makes sacred scenes feel quietly human and intimate.

image.alt: Correggio, Rest on the Flight into Egypt

viewing_tips: Notice Correggio's soft sfumato technique
The intimate scale creates a personal devotional atmosphere

items.title: Supper at Emmaus
items.description: A powerful Mannerist interpretation of the biblical moment when the resurrected Christ is recognized. Expect a heightened emotional tone, surprising color, and an atmosphere that feels more psychological than purely narrative.
viewing_tips: Notice the Eye of God in the triangle above Christ
The figures seem to lean in unexpected directions
Compare with Leonardo's more rational Last Supper

items.title: Spedalingo Altarpiece
items.description: An altarpiece associated with the Florentine Mannerist revolution. Rosso's style often favors sharp character, dramatic poses, and a bold sense of invention compared with earlier Renaissance harmony.
viewing_tips: Notice the jarring colors and angular forms
Rosso later worked at Fontainebleau in France

items.title: Musical Angel
items.description: A refined figure study with Rosso's distinctive expressive edge. Even in a single figure, the drawing and pose can feel charged - less calm 'beauty,' more personality and tension.
viewing_tips: Notice the unusual orange-red coloring
The intense expression distinguishes Rosso's style

items.title: Portrait of Eleanor of Toledo with Her Son
items.description: A court portrait associated with Medici power and image-making. Bronzino is famous for precision, cool elegance, and the way luxurious fabrics and jewels become statements of status as much as decoration.

image.alt: Bronzino, Portrait of Eleanor of Toledo with Her Son

viewing_tips: Study the incredible detail of the brocade dress
Eleanor's dress fabric was found preserved in her tomb
The son is Giovanni, future Cardinal de' Medici

items.title: Madonna del Popolo
items.description: A devotional work by Barocci, an artist known for emotional warmth, graceful movement, and color that bridges late Renaissance ideals with a more immediate, engaging spirituality.
viewing_tips: Notice the soft, pastel color palette
Barocci's warm style anticipated the Baroque

items.title: Saints John the Evangelist and Francis
items.description: A spiritual, visionary painting typical of El Greco's style: elongated forms, intense expression, and a sense that the figures belong to an inner world rather than ordinary physical space.

image.alt: El Greco, Saints John the Evangelist and Francis

viewing_tips: Notice El Greco's signature elongated figures
The otherworldly light suggests divine presence

items.title: Venus of Urbino
items.description: One of the most famous Renaissance nudes: Venus reclines in an interior setting, painted with Titian's hallmark mastery of color, flesh tones, and atmosphere. The work is central to the Venetian painting sequence on this floor.
viewing_tips: Notice the warm, glowing flesh tones
The dog symbolizes fidelity
Maids in the background prepare her wedding chest
This painting influenced Manet's Olympia

items.title: Leda and the Swan
items.description: A Venetian mythological subject known for theatrical energy and dramatic pictorial movement. Tintoretto is often recognized for bold compositions and a vivid, restless sense of action.
viewing_tips: Notice Tintoretto's dynamic brushwork
The scene captures movement and drama

items.title: Esther and Ahasuerus
items.description: A grand narrative scene by Veronese, known for elegant staging, rich color, and a sense of spectacle. His paintings often read like theater: beautifully arranged figures, architecture, and gesture.
viewing_tips: Notice the theatrical staging and rich costumes
Veronese excelled at grand narrative scenes

items.title: Verone (Panoramic Terrace)
items.description: A major terrace/viewpoint space along the First Floor route. It offers a pause in the visit and is also part of the museum's monumental architectural experience over the Arno side.
viewing_tips: Take a moment to enjoy views over the Arno
This is a good rest point midway through the floor

items.title: Caravaggio Room
items.description: A highlight section of the First Floor focused on Caravaggio and key works associated with his dramatic realism - strong contrasts of light and shadow, intense psychology, and direct physical presence.

items.title: Judith Slaying Holofernes
items.description: A powerful Baroque interpretation of the biblical heroine Judith. Artemisia's work is known for its intensity, realism, and the sheer force of the scene - an image that many visitors remember long after leaving.
viewing_tips: Notice the physical struggle depicted realistically
Artemisia painted several versions of this subject
Compare with the male artists' treatments of the same scene

items.title: Sacrifice of Isaac
items.description: A tense moment from the Abraham and Isaac story, presented with Caravaggio's signature realism and emotional immediacy. The scene is staged to feel close - almost uncomfortably present.
viewing_tips: Notice Isaac's terrified expression
The angel arrives at the last possible moment
Caravaggio used real models, often from the streets of Rome

items.title: Medusa
items.description: A striking image of Medusa's severed head, designed to shock and captivate. It's celebrated for its virtuoso naturalism and the sensation of an image that seems to confront the viewer directly.
viewing_tips: Painted on a ceremonial shield
The blood still spurts from the severed neck
A gift for the Grand Duke of Tuscany
Some believe it's Caravaggio's self-portrait

items.title: Bacchus
items.description: A sensuous, realistic depiction of Bacchus, god of wine. Caravaggio's approach turns mythology into something immediate and human - flesh, fruit, and gaze rendered with provocative closeness.
viewing_tips: Notice the incredibly realistic fruit still life
Bacchus seems to offer the viewer a glass of wine
The slightly spoiled fruit may symbolize mortality
X-rays revealed a tiny self-portrait in the wine carafe

items.title: Van Honthorst and the Caravaggisti
items.description: A section connected to 'night-light' painting - works where illumination from candles or lamps becomes the main dramatic engine. Artists in this orbit often explore how light shapes faces, objects, and mood in darkness.

items.title: Portrait of an Old Man
items.description: A moving portrait associated with Rembrandt's ability to suggest inner life through light, texture, and subtle expression - less about display, more about presence and humanity.

image.alt: Rembrandt, Portrait of an Old Man

viewing_tips: Notice how light emerges from darkness
Rembrandt's late works focus on psychological depth
The rough brushwork creates texture and life

items.title: Portrait of Isabella Brant
items.description: A portrait by Rubens, known for vitality, warmth, and confident brushwork. Compared with Rembrandt's introspection, Rubens often feels more openly energetic and luminous.

image.alt: Peter Paul Rubens, Portrait of Isabella Brant

viewing_tips: Isabella was Rubens' beloved first wife
Notice the warm, glowing skin tones typical of Rubens

items.title: Vasari Corridor - History
items.description: A short interpretive section explaining the origin and purpose of the Vasari Corridor - an elevated passage historically linking key Medici spaces and later associated with important collections.

items.title: Vasari Corridor - The Route
items.description: A section focusing on the corridor's path and its role in the city's Medici-era urban design, emphasizing how architecture and power were physically connected through controlled movement.

items.title: Vasari Corridor - The Roman Busts
items.description: A section introducing classical portraits and busts connected to the Uffizi's long tradition of collecting antiquities - an essential part of how the Medici framed culture, authority, and learning.
